question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course is extremely beneficial for anyone interested in doing academic research related to the field of genetics or biology. The course especially improved my skills in reading academic papers, writing research reports, and critiquing the ethics of study designs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different perspectives in the world of genome editing, as well as debates that I had never heard much about before the course. I also improved in my collaboration with other groups, and this was the first class where I had to learn how to synthesize a good amount of reading each week.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class brought up various ethical considerations of human research that I had never considered before. It also taught me how to digest scientific papers and produce a final term paper that could efficiently cite examples and generate solutions to various ethical issues posed. Lastly, I feel that this class really improved my communication and public speaking skills through various group projects and even just simply participating in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more ethically and critically about topics of human subjects research, how genetics research needs to be conducted in a manner that takes into consideration of the participant's rights and consent, and what regulations and guidelines are important to consider when designing an experiment/ study to examine the relationship between diseases and genetic information, as most, if not all the time, that information becomes a shared one among scientists, regions, and countries.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course structure was very intuitive, and felt similar to most lecture-based classes with increased time for discussion. Most classes consisted of a lecture related to a genomics research topic, and Professor Haga would briefly pause throughout some slides to allow for discussion and questions. The opportunity for asking questions was very beneficial at facilitating learning, and made me feel more comfortable asking questions in other classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked having some group work and having the opportunity to speak as a class about interesting topics where there were a variety of perspectives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that Professor Haga created a classroom environment that was very welcoming of questions and comments, which was really special in a class like this. I also liked reading what my peers said in the forum posts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Haga's lectures are top-down but very engaging. And I enjoyed how we were able to go see the HeLa cells in person at the lab -- a fascinating experience from the book we had read in class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topic of the course itself was very stimulating, as there are many ethical debates that can be sparked within the field of genetics. Beyond the content, Professor Haga is very knowledgeable in this field and truly understands everything in the lecture slides, making it very interesting to learn from her opinions and analysis of various topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really enjoyed learning about a variety of issues and perspectives, as this was the first ethics course I have ever taken. Super interesting!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought this class was very engaging. The culture was very welcoming, and it was really discussion-based. I feel as though Professor Haga and my peers really cared about what I said, and this sentiment was mutual. I also found it cool when we read about HeLa and then actually saw her cells in person! That was a very cool field trip that really made the class exciting. I feel like more field trips could be beneficial. In psych, I've heard the professor asks that his students participate in a research study of their choosing. It would be cool to ask students of this class to do the same for an individual or group project and talk about their experience, maybe discuss what makes the study ethical/unethical, etc. It would be cool to sit through an actual consent process from someone conducting a study at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made the class stimulating was the contents of the material. It made me think about how and why genomic research is done in the first place, and why regulations and policies are so important in helping to govern proper and ethical practices on the scientists' end. So many things can go wrong, and there are always room to improve.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While this course is one of the best FOCUS classes offered to first years, your liking of it will greatly depend on the amount of work you put in. In order to truly absorb the content and do well in this class, you must be willing to read the assigned papers thoroughly and participate a lot in class. Other than that, the exams throughout the semester are not too difficult so long as you have completed all assigned readings and take notes during lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you stay on top of the readings for every class and study thoroughly for each exam. For studying, focus on the topics discussed in class more than from the readings. And be sure to participate!

It also required me to be patient and persistent to understand the topics that we were reading about in synthetic biology. Now that I think about it my ability to read these papers improved so much over the course of the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning about the science was really stimulating and talking to everyone about the policy was as well

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dig in to the content and really try to understand papers don't just skim over them and the test will become easier.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them that this course is a lot of work and a huge time commitment. If considering taking this course, make sure you can handle the work load and also don't overload yourself with other work-heavy courses

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You have to work hard and participate but it's an interesting class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand the slides at least!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say if you like genetics and are interested in research or think you may be interested in research this is a great class to take. It really strengthens your understanding of the world of synthetic biology and often left me really curious about all of the possibilities that can come out of this field.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It'll be challenging and hard work but you will learn so much and be much better prepared for any career in science or policy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about wet lab assays, I learned about different genome databases, and I learned about applying genome technologies to medical specialties.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use some of the most popular gene databases regarding genes, protein, SNPs, etc. I also learned a lot about sequencing techniques and how they are practically applied in a research and clinical setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Skills of doing bioinformatics without coding, presenting a paper. Understanding modern technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Recent evolutionary sequencing techniques, basic bioinformatics searching skills, and widely-used database.

response_text:
1) Using gene databases

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different databases and how to navigate them, a lot about different sequencing and genomic technologies, and about applications of sequencing and genomic profiling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Differences between genome technologies, how to navigate genome databases, how to apply understanding of genetics and genomics to precision medicine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about current technologies in sequencing, such as single cell RNA seq, etc. I also was able to learn about bioinformatics and navigate databases to understand clinical data and gene variants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to use genomics databases 
2. Current genomic technologies and policies 
3. A lot of new genetics material and gene editing

response_text: Dr. Haga is amazing. The content of the class is fascinating and she is a really engaging lecturer. The assignments and exams are hard but she does a really good job of preparing us.
